pros: Work life balance , equality and diversity and inclusion in every area of work , great suppprtive management
cons: Regulatory processes are very stringent. Things happen very slow

pros: Lots of pros in working there
cons: No down side that I could think

pros:
- Support for initiatives
- Positive working environment
- EDI
- Transparency and zero tolerance for fraud and bullying
- They value people
cons:
- Can be bureaucratic
- Some top management carry the blaming culture
- Sometimes top management don't care about work life balance yet preach it in meetings.
- UK appointment staff receive massive benefits and pay despite EDI policies and 'save money' advice is used when basic improvements are required.

pros:
- Wonderful and friendly people to work with
- Great policies in place for Equality, Diversity and Inclusion
- Flexible working hours in some departments
-

cons: quite less opportunities in Area of growth

pros:
Often, several opportunities to branch out in your role.  If you work in a regional hub this will increase further.
Very interesting projects to get involved in.
Fantastic opportunities to travel to other countries.
cons:
Transitioning from a charity to a business.  The human capital structure isn't there yet, although restructuring is happening.  
There are rules on the number of years you can spend in a country which means there's often a lot of coming and going as people move into position, change everything and then move on.
Salary is good overseas (in some regions) and as teacher you can be looked after very well (accommodation, flights and great BUPA healthcare) but not great in the UK.

pros: Interesting work, multicultural and diverse working environment, generally supportive management, some travel opportunities depending on the post, for some posts travel requirements are high, access to interesting and influential people. Good if you are a specialist in a particular geography or discipline.
cons: Complicated matrix management can mean that project ownership and accountabilities not always clear. Reduced funding means in some geographies programming decisions are unduly influenced by views of funders and stakeholders rather than core mission and vision. Salaries are low in comparison to expectations and working hours.

review_title: Positive experience - if you choose to make it that
pros:
Good salary and benefits 
Friendly atmosphere 
Opportunities for some professional development - with the right qualifications
cons:
Your experience can vary quite a bit depending on who your line manager is.
Salary increases and chances for professional development very limited if you don't have a DELTA

pros:
Flat organisation, great people, transparent processes and  fantastic learning opportunities.
Equal opportunities and diversity are serious matters at the British Council.
You get a lot of satisfaction from contributing to making a difference in people's lives
Only 37.5 hours/week, flexible hours.
44 days annual leave (including public holidays)
cons:
Work/life balance could be hard to achieved in some departments
Slow decision making and  below market salaries but it's still a great place to start one's career from.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Officer in Dubai
pros:
Comfortable Work Environment 
Equality, Diversity and Inclusion Vision
British Council values
cons:
Work Life Balance   (home working/flexible working hours scheme is allowed for certain titles based on the job nature)
Slow Promotion Opportunities

pros:
Equal opportunities employer
International repute
Innumerable professional development opportunities
Good training and workshops
cons: Locally recruited staff don't enjoy the same benefits as UK appointed staff or staff who relocate

cons: It is not easy to get a higher position within the company.
